Fields.DialogueText: AAAAAH!
Bezbozhnik? Are you all right?
I-- I'm fine.
I just had a nightmare. That's all.
And that doesn't bother you?
I have nightmares *every* night, Captain. It's nothing.

Fields.MenuText: ...I do too.
You were loud enough to wake the dead.
If you're screaming, you're not fine.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Don't joke like that. It's not funny.
... Maybe not, but this is normal for me.
Oh, Captain... I'm so sorry. But that means you understand, right?
Listen. When you get left at the bottom of the sea for a decade, you have nightmares about drowning.
And when you used to believe in heaven, and then realize there's no such thing--
Well, you have nightmares about getting turned away at the Pearly Gates.
... I see.
It is what it is. There's no sense complaining about it.
Well, if you ever do want to complain, I'm here.
*ALARM*
Thank you, Captain. I'd rather take it out on these Morganas.
Then let's give them nightmares.
@BATTLE
I have some interesting news.
What is it, Cap?
We're going to have a Soviet dignitary on board for the foreseeable future.
Oh dear. Can I ask who...?
Says here... Fleet Flag Officer Makarov.
Blyat! Why *him?*

Fields.MenuText: You don't like him much?
What'd he ever do to you?
Isn't he part of the Soviet fleet?

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, but my patriotism doesn't outweigh my pride.
I hate his guts!
Oh, you have no idea, Cap. You have no idea.
*On podonok*- He's a scumbag. He doesn't think Belles are real.
That's... certainly an opinion.
He's a materialist. Believes anything supernatural is 'the madness of crowds.'
Well. We'll have to keep an eye on him.
Of course, Cap. But I'm not looking forward to this.
You don't have to. Just be polite.
Easier said than done.
*ALARM*
Let's get to the bridge.
Right behind you.
@BATTLE
And this is... politically complicated. In terms of my League credentials, he doesn't exactly supersede my command.
But he *is* empowered to pull you provisionally out of active League registration - and out of my hands - if he objects to the way I run the show. So we're stuck with him.
Hey, Bez, I have some reports for you.
Ugh.
Something wrong?
I don't like that nickname, Cap.
Wait, really? Why?
Bez-bozh-nik means "without-god-person." When you call me Bez, you're calling me "without."

Fields.MenuText: I'm sorry, I didn't know.
Is there something you'd rather I call you?
Yeah, I know. I just... thought you were okay with it. I'm sorry.

Fields.DialogueText: It's fine. You were trying to be friendly.
Thanks. It's fine. You were trying to be friendly.
Well, you see...
I haven't found a nickname that works yet. But when I do, I'll let you know.
Is it that hard to find one?
Oh, you have no idea. "Bezbozhnik" is a masculine-gendered word. And I'm sure you know this, but--
For Russian nicknames? The rules are flexible, but... well, there are rules. And none of the ideas the crew have suggested work for me.
And English-friendly ones are no better. Not Bez, not Boz--
Nn... not unless you want to call me a deity.
And -nik... just means person.
Exactly. Do you see why I'm having trouble?
Yes. We'll both have to think about it, I suppose.
*ALARM*
... If the Morgs give us a second to think.
@BATTLE
Welcome aboard, Officer Makarov.
*Privet,* Kapitan. I trust you're well.
Bezbozhnik is eager to greet you, sir.
Hm.
Pleased to see you again, Officer.
... Kapitan, we need to discuss the state of your ship.
Of course.
It seems your crew shares the popular delusion that "Comrades of the Fleet" exist.

Fields.MenuText: I've seen them with my own eyes.
She's standing right here, you know.
With all due respect...

Fields.DialogueText: Are you questioning my authority, Captain?
I thought you were reasonable, comrade.
Sad. I'd thought you were more rational than this.
No. But--
Is it really rational to ignore clear evidence?
Sailors are superstitious, and it's easy to lose one's senses. The water in a mirage is merely sand, yes?
While I am aboard this ship, no member of this crew is to refer to, or speak to, "Belles" in any way, shape, or form. Understood?
... Yes, Officer Makarov.
*ALARM*
Do you also think Morganas are a delusion, comrade?
@BATTLE
You can--
*ahem*
[sad violin music]
Bezbozhnik? Are you all right?
Take a guess.
Ah... I was afraid of that.
Everyone is ignoring me when Officer Makarov is around. I could poke someone in the eye and they'd pretend not to notice.
Do you know how that feels, Cap?

Fields.MenuText: It must be rough.
They're just following orders.
You want me to countermand him?

Fields.DialogueText: ... It would cause more problems than it solves.
That's no excuse! Is it?
Oh, Captain, you have no idea.
I feel like I'm going insane, and it's only going to get worse the longer this goes on.
Well....
*CLANK*
... And something's broken.
*ALARM*
Oh, this day just keeps getting better and better.
You've survived every bad day we've had so far.
Knock on wood, Cap.
@BATTLE
It's really strange, Captain. That breakdown the other day...
Nothing was wrong with the ship. Physically. We'd just replaced that piston.
So what do you think is wrong?
Some of the sailors think it's a ghost. Others, well....
Ghosts? What is this nonsense?
Eep!
The ship's been breaking down. We're discussing how to handle it.
... As you were. But how do ghosts come into it?
The crew are superstitious.
Another irrationality to quash.
Of course.
As you were, Captain.
Is he gone?
Yes. How are you holding up?
Well, let's put it this way. I've been playing the Danse Macabre since sunrise.
That might explain the rumours.
Do you think there's a ghost aboard?

Fields.MenuText: I don't believe in ghosts.
I try to keep an open mind.
Didn't your old crew....?

Fields.DialogueText: ... People died aboard this ship, yes.
Probably wise. The world's full of things we don't understand.
Morganas are rather ghostly, aren't they?
Apropos of nothing--
You're beginning to sound like Officer Makarov, Captain.
*ALARM*
People do call them "ghost ships..."
Speak of the devil and she will appear.
@BATTLE
Can I sit here, Captain?
Go ahead.
You hungry?
Not really. ... I don't want to be alone.
Then let's eat.
Thank you for not ignoring me, Captain.
It's the least I can do. You look exhausted.
... Nightmares again. I'm fine.
Captain... do you believe in God?

Fields.MenuText: Of course.
Of course not.
I don't want to talk about it.

Fields.DialogueText: That's your right, but can I...?
Go ahead.
You say that as if it's obvious. But any evidence....
I wish I could agree with you.
If we don't have faith, what are we?
There's no proof that God exists. And yet, it's hard to prove a negative.
There's so much suffering in the world, Cap.
If God does exist, I think the best thing we can do...
... is to *ignore* him.
What's brought this on?
Between Officer Makarov and the nightmares I've been having... I've been thinking about religion a lot.
So humor me, Cap. Do you believe in God?
*ALARM*
... If there is a God, they sure have a sense of humor.
@BATTLE
What's going on? The bridge went dark!
We've had another breakdown. I'm sure it's nothing to be worried about, Cap--
*CLANK*
*GROOOOOOAN*
-- It might be something to worry about.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think it's saboteurs?
Do you think you're fit for service?
Do you think you'll be all right?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course. There's nothing wrong with me.
Yes, Captain. I'm not going to sink just because something's gone a little haywire.
I think I'd know if someone aboard wanted me dead.
You hope you'd know.
This sounds like more than a little haywire.
I'm not saying there is! Just--
*ALARM*
I'll be fine. But the Rusalki can smell blood in the water.
Then let's finish them off. Before we have bigger problems.
@BATTLE
I got bad news and worse news, Cap. Which do you want first?

Fields.MenuText: Bad.
Let's go with worse.
Is there any *good* news?

Fields.DialogueText: Blyat, you're a bloody optimist.
Sensible. All right.
Scared to bite the bullet, huh?
The worse news is-
The bad news is--
We don't have any good news, and we're not likely to get any.
*ALARM*
I guess no news is good news.
Very funny, Cap.
No. I just want a full view of the situation.
You're a fountain of pessimism. Something good has to happen sometime.
@BATTLE
So let me get this straight.
Fleet Officer Makarov is so concerned with our mission that he's ignoring the advice of the entire engineering team.
That's right, Cap.
He thinks that some mines in the North Atlantic are worth endangering you.
Yep.
Not to mention the entire goddamn crew. And potentially the rest of our fleet.
Da.

Fields.MenuText: It's madness! How can he think this is right?
I'm halfway tempted to arrest him.
We need to suck it up. This won't get any better.

Fields.DialogueText: All of the breakdowns have been minor, and he doesn't want to dignify the... supernatural side of the rumours.
Meaning the ghost?
And my existence.
He's our commanding officer as long as he's aboard. We'd need a better reason than this. But...
Of course, but--
I can't stand it anymore, Cap.
If we don't get him off this ship ASAP, I'm going to snap.
I'll see what I can do, but... no promises.
*ALARM*
GRRRRRRRAAAAAAAH--
Oh, she's going to tear those Morganas apart!
Let's hope she doesn't tear Officer Makarov apart, too.
@BATTLE
AAH!
What's going on? Status report!
I-- I saw the ghost!

Fields.MenuText: Not you too!
I knew it - there *was* a ghost!
Are you sure it wasn't another nightmare?

Fields.DialogueText: I know. I *know.* But he was right in front of me. Clear as day.
Save the celebration, Cap! We've got a real problem.
That would be the logical explanation, but...
Whoa, whoa, let's back up a bit. What did the ghost look like?
A British sailor from the Great War. Part of my old crew. I knew him the way you know people in dreams, but...
His eyes looked like glass. And his body was bloated. Covered in barnacles.
He says to me, "The locket. Where's the locket?" And, just like that, he was gone.
"The locket," huh...?
I want to believe it was just a nightmare, but--
*ALARM*
Well, whether or not it was a nightmare...
We've got some real "ghosts" to fight.
Let's sink 'em. Before the other ghost comes back.
@BATTLE
Another breakdown? This is getting out of hand.
What else could go wrong?
*ALARM*
Captain, you have the *worst* timing!
@BATTLE
With everything going on aboard, this samovar was a good investment.
Mmm. You really should thank the crew member who suggested we get one.
All right. Thank you, dear.
What did you say you were going by, again?
As a nickname? Haven't decided yet.

Fields.MenuText: Didn't you want a Russian nickname?
Doesn't 'Mishka' mean 'little bear'?
If you can't decide, I'm happy to call you Bezbozhnik.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm more of a seal than a bear. But thank you.
Appreciated. But it doesn't really suit me.
Da. But there's so many of them.
I'm thinking... something starting with L. Like my old callsign.
But I can't quite decide what.
Well, let me know when you're ready, and I'll tell the crew.
Appreciated, Cap.
I feel so much better. The repairs must be done.
Let's go take a look.
Mmm.
You're cute when you're smug, B-
Our father who art in heaven, hallowed be thy name--
Bezbozhnik? I have some reports here-
Oh. Is this a bad time?
Negative, Captain.
But you were--
Praying? Yes.

Fields.MenuText: I thought you were an atheist.
The sailor's prayer, huh?
Are you reconsidering your beliefs, then?

Fields.DialogueText: Hell's bells, no.
I am *now.* But I wasn't always.
Hm?
"Lord, if I make it out of this alive, I swear I'll be better?"
Something like that.
My choices in a moment of weakness do not define me.
How does that work? You woke up after you'd been raised.
I don't want to pry, but if there's anything I can do...
There isn't.
Are you sure?
... I was praying for the souls of my crew. My *old* crew.
The British one?
Da. I... I want to keep ignoring Him. I want to believe that my old crew is at peace because there's nothing left of them.
I don't *want* to believe in the supernatural. But with everything that's been going on...
... You can't help but try whatever you can? Throw things at the wall and see what sticks?
*Pravda,* Captain. ... If I thought that I could ignore this, I would, but--
*ALARM*
Well, we can't ignore *this.*
Indeed. Battle stations, everyone!
@BATTLE
[violin music]
Bezbozhnik? I know you're down here...
Oh, there you are.
Is that a hymn?
A fantasia on one, yes.

Fields.MenuText: You really have got religion.
Are you sure you should be?
I see. Take your pain and make it art.

Fields.DialogueText: It was *stuck* in my *head.* If you're not going to be helpful, stop talking.
Everyone's pretending I don't exist, remember? I'll be fine.
This is barely art. It's just variations on a theme.
If you say so.
You still take requests, right?
Why?
Could you play that lullaby for me? The one your daughter taught you?
... You're a cruel, cruel captain.
Hey, I just want to help.
*ALARM*
Well, now I can't take requests. Just orders.
@BATTLE
*FWOOSH*
There's a fire aboard! To work, comrades.
You heard him, let's move!
It... hurts...
I know. We got you.
SSSSSS...
The fire's out.
Khorosho. Return to your stations.
Status report?
I'm... I'm fine, Cap.

Fields.MenuText: There's smoke coming out of your nose.
You just had a catastrophic breakdown.
I'll take you at your word.

Fields.DialogueText: Appreciated- *COUGH, COUGH*
*COUGH* That won't stop me.
*COUGH COUGH*
I... I can't argue with that evidence, but...
No, but dying certainly will.
You still sound like hell.
Do you think ... it was sabotage, Cap?
There's no sign of it. If we've got saboteurs, they're clever.
... Engines just don't blow for no reason.
Then maybe it was the ghost.
*COUGH* ... Don't joke about these things, Cap.
Fair. But either way, it's inexplicable.
... You know, before this...
... Officer Makarov sent a sailor to the brig for talking about me. Not even *to* me.
... I'm so sorry.
*Nichego ne popishesh'.* It can't be helped.
*ALARM*
... And neither can this.
@BATTLE
The Morgana mist is thicker than usual. I'd recommend caution.
Your recommendation has been noted. But we're only picking up a few ships.
We engage. Destroy all hostiles and lay the mines.
... On your orders.
The mist is getting thicker! Visibility's dropping!

Fields.MenuText: We have our orders. Keep going.
We fall back.
Drop the mines and prepare to retreat.

Fields.DialogueText: This is insubordination!
Captain, this is suicide!
I can't risk my ship like this.
Where's Bezbozhnik?
No one's seen her all day, Captain.
I can't disobey a direct order.
They're coming from all directions! We can't shake them!
Get them off our back!
@BATTLE
Bezbozhnik, where are you?! We're getting overrun!
Hhhhhhsssssss.... do you know who you can trust?
I-
The Rusalki.... I've never seen so many of them...
Get them all! Start with the closest!
Officer, I'm not a Rusalka! Stop pointing at me!

Fields.MenuText: This can't go on.
He's unfit to command.
Get Paranoia first!

Fields.DialogueText: I'll try to restrain him.
You're finally talking sense!
*Thank* you, Cap!
HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA!
Can you trust them? Any of them?
Look at how they've treated you. Ignored, forgotten, left to rot...
Turn your guns on them, or they'll turn them on you first...
Bezbozhnik, snap out of it! I'm not going to hurt you!
*BOOM*
@BATTLE
Look at that captain. See how the scoundrel plays with your heart... ready to twist a knife in your back as soon as you turn...
A sad world, when even your lover lies to your face... sink, and forget it all!
Fire at me all you want! Your real enemies are on your own deck!
Th-the Rusalka... Am I seeing things, or ... No! It doesn't matter!
Take her away. Make her go away!

Fields.MenuText: He's completely lost it.
We're not going to do that.
You hate to see a good man go down like this...

Fields.DialogueText: I don't. This is what he deserves.
*Thank* you, Cap.
You say that like he was fine before.
It doesn't matter- either way, this is madness. We're not getting rid of our ship's protector.
*Enough!* Take the traitor captain to the brig WITH the Rusalka.
Are you joking?
Bezbozhnik's one of us. We're tired of treating her like scum on your orders.
*BOOM*
You can't trust them. They're just waiting to twist the kni-
Zakroy svoy proklyatyy rot shlyukhi. You've spewed enough!
@BATTLE
Paranoia's scuppered, where she belongs.
Good riddance. But there's more where she came from.
@BATTLE
That was grueling. Status report.
Besides what you've already seen?
The crew members who got hit hardest are in the sick bay now. Most of them will recover.
Flag Officer Makarov is another story. He will most likely be discharged.

Fields.MenuText: It's a shame. He was brave. A good man.
So much for your materialism.
I'll be glad to see the back of him.

Fields.DialogueText: Makarov was *not* a materialist.
He was neither.
You and me both.
He was a fool and a coward.
Really, now?
A materialist believes only what can be supported by objective reality. Things that can be seen and felt in the world outside the mind.
But in the name of materialism, Makarov hid in the world *inside* his mind. A world where there are no Belles... and thus, no Morganas.
... And it was his undoing.
Exactly, Cap. Like I said. A coward and a fool.
Well. Let's hope neither of us go down that path.
I won't. And to be honest? I doubt you will, either.
It's such a relief to be able to talk to you again.
It's a relief to me, too. I was getting tired of hiding.
We all were. It was like there was a cloud over the ship. Now it's gone.
Ah, that's the Captain! I have to go.
Remember how you were saying we never get good news?
You have some for me? I'm shocked.
With the engine fire, Command's agreed you need repairs. We're going into drydock.
Thank goodness. And here I was starting to think everyone had forgotten me.

Fields.MenuText: You've got people in your corner, no matter what.
How could *anyone* forget you?
You're a valuable asset. There's no way we'd let you down.

Fields.DialogueText: Then I'd best keep being valuable.
Depressingly easily. But it can't be helped.
That still feels strange, but I'll take it.
People care about you. You have friends aboard. And I'm proud to count myself as one of them.
And something more, besides.
*ALARM*
...Ah. I guess I should thank *them,* too.
For what?
For giving me the chance to prove it.
@BATTLE
I love you *so much.*
I finally figured it out, Cap.
Figured what out? The ghost?
No. If there's one aboard, he's been well-behaved since Makarov left.
I figured out the nickname situation.
You found a Russian one you like?
M-hm. "Lyubov" starts with an L. And I like the way the nicknames sound. "Lyuba" for friends, "Lyubotchka" for, uh, family.
Doesn't "Lyubov" mean "love?"
Yes. Yes, it does.

Fields.MenuText: I like it. It suits you.
You're a sentimental old girl, aren't you?
Well.. it's less of a mouthful.

Fields.DialogueText: And you wouldn't have me any other way, would you?
I know, right? Even the Americans should be able to handle it.
Thank you. I was worried you'd find it too soft.
Well, you have a softer side...
Hey, now, that's going too far.
Not for the world.
Captain! Come quickly, you need to see this!
What? What is it?
The dock workers found... something terrible!
I'll take a look. Lyubotchka- Come on!
Right behind you, Cap.
Family?
My daughters, and... you, if you're comfortable with it.
... I can't look. What'd they find?
Oh, it's terrible! No wonder we were haunted.
Is that... what I think it is?
A skeletal hand, Captain. It was in the hull, between the plates. And here-
It was clasping this.
A locket?
That looks just like the one from my nightmare, Cap. Do you think it could be...?

Fields.MenuText: If it belongs to the ghost, we'll put it to rest.
How did this get here?
If it's from your old crew, we should return it to the British.

Fields.DialogueText: I... I couldn't agree more.
We don't know. Could've been stuck in there when the ship went down, and the Soviet breakers just didn't notice.
... Absolutely. It needs to be returned.
... There's Morganas coming.
Are you good to go, Lyubotchka?
My guns still work. Let's make them run.
@BATTLE
Well. Thanks to the locket, we've identified the hand.
It belonged to Eric Martin. He was part of my crew when I...
They found all that out from a locket?
From the picture inside it. His old sweetheart is still alive.
She joined the ATS in the Great War and got called in when they re-founded it. A few questions to the right people, and... well... we found her.
So what happens now?
We returned the locket to his family and the hand will be buried with ... well, the rest of him.

Fields.MenuText: Good. I'm glad he's been put to rest.
It's a shame it didn't happen sooner.

Fields.DialogueText: I am too. It's a weight off my shoulders.
Mm. From what the dock crew told me, it was wedged in there. They couldn't get it out without a prybar.

Fields.MenuText: I'm just glad this is over.

Fields.DialogueText: Me too, Cap.
Well... hopefully now all this ghost business will be put to rest.
Hopefully. But I think there's a rational explanation for it all, Cap.
Care to enlighten me?
Well-
*ALARM*
Tell you later, Cap! For now, let's deal with these witches.
@BATTLE
Love is a powerful thing.
... Indeed.
Ah, Captain! You always know where to find the best tea.
The secret ingredient is a shot of rum.
Why am I not surprised?
So... you said you had a rational explanation for our 'haunting'?
Indeed I do.
Remember, I am not just Lyubov-the-person. I am also Bezbozhnik-the-vessel.
If the vessel is damaged, I am injured. And... in a way? Vice versa.
When Makarov started giving those ridiculous orders...

Fields.MenuText: ... You have a thing about being ignored.
... You couldn't tolerate the disrespect.
... You couldn't take his faux-materialism.

Fields.DialogueText: If you mean "a complex," say it to my face.
I couldn't. But it went deeper than that.
I couldn't. But this was about more than philosophy.
... I still have nightmares about drowning, Cap. Almost every night.
About sinking, and about... being left for dead. Forever, this time.
I'm so sorry.
It can't be helped. But Makarov's nonsense... it was like a *waking* version of those nightmares.
Left to drown alone.
.... And you were so unhappy it was making you sick.
Vernyy. Everything the 'ghost' did can be explained that way.
The chill in the air? A fan run amok. The sightings? Superstitious crew on edge, and my own nightmares.
The engine fire? Stress so great that I couldn't bear it anymore.
Hm. That does make sense. But there's one flaw in your theory.
Hit me.
The ghost you saw mentioned the locket. But you had no idea it was there, didn't you?
No. I suppose I could have known subconsciously.
In a manner of speaking, it was right under my skin.
...I'll sleep easier knowing that there's no need to pray.
I think we all will.
*ALARM*
They can't let us get a word in edgewise, can they?
It's enough to make you paranoid.
@BATTLE
But you're not wrong.
So, Lyubotchka... Is your crisis of unfaith over?
I think so, yes.
I don't know why I woke up religious. But I know that I don't have to stay that way.
I'm unhappy believing things without evidence for them. And with an explanation for the ghost... Well, I don't have to.
If it works for you, it works for you. Just don't end up like Makarov.
I can assure you, that won't be the case.
... You know what's really funny?
What?
You called the ghost thing a crisis of unfaith, but... you could say I've had two, this last mission.
Really, now? What was the other one?
... I thought Paranoia was right.

Fields.MenuText: Oh, come on, her entire thing is  that she's wrong.
... Sorry to hear that.
She *wasn't.* You're one of us no matter what.

Fields.DialogueText: I know. And thank you for that.
It's fine. I'm used to it.
Isn't it just?
But the things she said... were also the things my heart tells me, when I can't sleep.
That I'm always going to be... not one thing or the other. Not Christian and not fully atheist. Not British and not fully Russian. And because of that...
My heart says no one will stand by me. No one will speak up for me. No one will care.
... But you *did*. You all did.
Lyubotchka, listen to me. As long as I am your Captain...
Paranoia will be *wrong*. You will always have someone to stand up for you. No matter what.
Oh, Captain...
Nothing like this will *ever* happen again. You have my word.
Mop up the stragglers!
You keep this up, we might be able to speak freely.
@BATTLE
... It feels insane. But based on the evidence....
I have faith in you, Captain.
You don't have to take it on faith. I'll prove it to you. As many times as you need.
No one will ever love me.
And I will *always* love you. As long as you'll have me.
Then let's go prove it to each other.
I thought you'd never ask.
